definition:
Here is a sample result for the function, essentially classifying its
uniqueness :

**Proposition 1:** $\mu$ is the unique mapping
${\mathbb{N}^{*}}\to{{\mathbb}{Z}}$ such that $$\begin{aligned}
\mu(1)&=&1 \\
\sum_{d|n}\mu(d)&=&0\textrm{ for all }n>1\end{aligned}$$

**Proof:** By induction, there can only be one function with these
properties. $\mu$ clearly satisfies (1), so take some $n>1$. Let $p$ be
some prime factor of $n$, and let $m$ be the product of all the prime
factors of $n$. $$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{d|n}\mu(d)&=&\sum_{d|m}\mu(d) \\
&=&\sum_{\substack{d|m\\p\nmid d}}\mu(d) +\sum_{\substack{d|m\\p\mid d}}\mu(d) \\
&=&\sum_{d|m/p}\mu(d)-\sum_{d|m/p}\mu(d) \\
&=&0\end{aligned}$$
